Situation1: A patient with a common illness like strep throat has come to the clinic for a check-up.
Expectation2: Respect the privacy and confidentiality of the people you are helping
Situation2: A client quietly shares a private concern while filling out forms at the check-in table.
Story: Today was one of those days when my two worlds collided. As a doctor, I was seeing patients in the clinic, and my first appointment was a young woman with a sore throat. She looked anxious, and after a quick exam, I was confident it was strep throat. I knew I needed to prescribe antibiotics and explain the treatment plan clearly, as my patients expect thorough care and reassurance from me. But just as I was about to write the prescription, my phone buzzed with a message from the community center where I volunteer. One of the clients I’d helped earlier in the week had quietly confided in me about a sensitive family issue while filling out forms. Now, the center’s coordinator was asking if I could share any details to help connect her with resources. I felt torn—my duty as a doctor demanded my full attention to my patient, while my role as a volunteer required me to protect the client’s privacy. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I found myself frozen, unsure which responsibility should come first.
